questions.text: A patient with pneumonia is prescribed azithromycin, but the pharmacist discovers that the medication has expired. In accordance with hospital waste disposal practices, which colour-coded container should be used to discard the expired azithromycin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Expired azithromycin, being a clinical pharmaceutical waste, must be discarded in a yellow plastic bag as per national colour-coded biomedical waste disposal guidelines.

  • Clinical waste, including expired antibiotics and medicines, should be disposed of using yellow plastic bags, which may be orange/red in some hospitals.
  • Proper labelling, securing, and limiting the fill to two-thirds of the bag is essential before incineration.
  • If there's any risk of leakage, double-bagging is advised.
  • This segregation prevents contamination and ensures safe pharmaceutical disposal.

Explanation of Other Options:

Red bag (Option A): Used for contaminated recyclable items like plastic tubing, gloves, not for medicines.

Blue bag (Option C): Used for glassware or metallic implants, not suitable for pharmaceuticals.

Green bag (Option D): For biodegradable general waste, not used for any biomedical/pharmaceutical materials.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with a painful, red, swollen wound on his right thigh that has a fluctuant, pus-filled centre. He also has a fever and an elevated white blood cell count. If MRSA is suspected, what is the most effective method to prevent transmission of MRSA in the ward?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hand washing is the most effective method to prevent MRSA transmission in hospital settings.

  • MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus) spreads predominantly through contact transmission, especially via the contaminated hands of healthcare workers.
  • Contact spread of infection has assumed paramount importance in hospitals, and hand hygiene is the central strategy in reducing nosocomial transmission.
  • Alcohol-based sanitisers or soap and water are recommended for effective hand hygiene, especially before and after patient contact.
  • MRSA colonisation is common in skin and soft tissue lesions, and intensive care patients are at the highest risk.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fumigation (Option A): Ineffective, as MRSA spreads by direct contact, not the airborne route. Not part of routine MRSA control.

Cleaning surfaces with chlorhexidine (Option B): Helpful adjunct but not the most effective measure; hand hygiene remains the primary method.

Use of rifampicin in prophylaxis (Option D): Not used for MRSA prophylaxis; overuse may promote resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ESKAPE pathogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stenotrophomonas maltophilia is not part of the ESKAPE group.

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, although an important opportunistic and nosocomial pathogen with intrinsic resistance to multiple antibiotics, is not part of the ESKAPE group.
  • It is usually sensitive to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and is associated with respiratory tract infections, urinary tract infections, and bacteremia in immunocompromised individuals.
  • ESKAPE pathogens are a group of multidrug-resistant (MDR) organisms that are highly significant in hospital-acquired infections because they can "escape" the action of most antibiotics. They are responsible for the majority of nosocomial infections and present a major therapeutic challenge.

The acronym ESKAPE stands for:

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: There are many infections where transmission occurs through blood. Which of the following is not a bloodborne infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hepatitis E is transmitted by the faecal-oral route, not blood.

It lacks a carrier state, does not cause chronic hepatitis, and is known for high mortality in pregnant women.

Explanation of Other Options:

HIV (Option A): Transmitted by blood, sexual contact, and vertically. Causes a chronic lifelong infection.

Hepatitis B (Option C): Transmitted via blood, sexual contact, and perinatal; causes both acute and chronic infection.

Hepatitis C (Option D): Primarily transmitted via blood (e.g. injection drug use, transfusion); high risk of chronic hepatitis.

questions.text: A nurse is administering an injection to a patient and inadvertently pierces herself with the needle after injecting the patient. Upon learning that the patient is HIV-positive, the nurse is concerned about the risk of transmission. The first dose of Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV should be taken preferably within how many hours of exposure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PEP (Post-Exposure Prophylaxis) is most effective when initiated as early as possible following potential HIV exposure via needle-stick injuries.

  • Preferred initiation time: Within 2 hours of exposure.
  • Maximum allowable window: Up to 72 hours post-exposure, though efficacy diminishes with time delay.
  • Duration of treatment: 28 days with a triple-drug antiretroviral regimen (commonly two NRTIs + one integrase inhibitor or protease inhibitor).
  • Risk of transmission from needle-stick injury (HIV-positive source): ~0.3%
  • Immediate actions post-injury:
    • Wash the wound with soap and water
    • Notify the infection control team
    • Begin risk assessment and initiate PEP

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: A patient who was recently treated for a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) abscess is seen for a follow-up appointment. On examination, he is found to be a nasal carrier of MRSA. What is the most appropriate treatment for eradicating nasal colonisation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mupirocin 2% intranasal ointment is the most effective treatment for nasal carriage of MRSA.

  • MRSA colonisation, particularly in nasal carriers, is a significant source of recurrent infections and hospital transmission.
  • Mupirocin 2% applied to both nostrils for 5-10 days is proven to eradicate nasal MRSA colonisation.
  • This intervention is especially important in infection control protocols, preoperative decolonisation, and reducing recurrence in recurrent skin/soft tissue infections.

Explanation of Other Options:

Chlorhexidine (Option A): Antiseptic for skin; used in MRSA protocols but not intranasally.

Rifampicin (Option B): Sometimes used systemically with fusidic acid, but not recommended alone or intranasally.

Ethyl alcohol (Option D): Effective on skin but not suitable for mucosal decolonisation, like the nares.

questions.text: Adequacy of pasteurisation is tested by which of the following test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Phosphatase test because alkaline phosphatase enzyme, normally present in raw milk, is inactivated when pasteurisation is properly carried out. Detecting residual enzyme activity after pasteurisation indicates inadequate heating, making this test a reliable indicator of pasteurisation adequacy.

  • Purpose: To verify the adequacy of pasteurisation in milk and dairy products.
  • Principle: The enzyme alkaline phosphatase, present in raw milk, is destroyed when pasteurisation is correctly performed. If an active enzyme is detected, pasteurisation was inadequate.
  • Significance:
    • Positive test after pasteurisation → contamination or insufficient heating.
    • Ensures safety by confirming proper microbial destruction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Eijkman test (Option A): Used to detect Escherichia coli in water by its ability to ferment lactose at 44°C with gas production; not used for pasteurisation testing.

Coliform test (Option B): Detects coliform bacteria to indicate faecal contamination; important for hygiene checks but not for determining adequacy of pasteurisation.

Catalase test (Option C): Differentiates catalase-producing bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus) from non-catalase producers (e.g., Streptococcus); unrelated to pasteurisation assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not disposed of by incineration according to BMW 2016 Guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Urobag because recyclable contaminated plastic waste, such as Urobags, is not incinerated; instead, it is subjected to autoclaving or hydroclaving followed by shredding, and then sent to an authorised recycler. Incineration is generally reserved for waste like human anatomical waste and other large-volume soiled infectious materials.

  • BMW 2016 Guidelines specify segregation of biomedical waste into specific categories with corresponding treatment methods.
  • Incineration: For large solid infectious waste like anatomical waste, amputated limbs, animal carcasses, soiled dressings (in some cases), and similar waste.
  • Plastics (including urobags): Require pre-treatment by autoclaving/hydroclaving + shredding before recycling, not incineration.
  • Rationale: Prevents the release of toxic emissions from burning plastics.

Explanation of Other Options:

Discarded linen (Option A): Generally categorised as soiled waste and may be incinerated if heavily contaminated and unsuitable for disinfection/reuse.

Chemical waste (Option B): Treated chemically for neutralisation; in certain cases, incineration may be used depending on composition.

Soiled waste (Option C): Includes contaminated dressings, cotton swabs, and similar items; may be incinerated if not suitable for other treatments.

questions.text: Metallic body implants are discarded in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Blue bag because, according to BMW 2016 Guidelines, glassware and metallic body implants are disposed of in a blue cardboard box with a blue label. These items are either sent for recycling after proper disinfection and cleaning or treated by autoclaving/microwaving/hydroclaving before disposal.

  • Blue cardboard box with blue label: For glassware (broken or discarded), contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules (except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste), and metallic body implants.
  • Rationale: Ensures safe handling and prevents injury from sharp or rigid metallic/glass waste while allowing for recycling after disinfection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Red bag (Option A): For contaminated recyclable waste such as plastic tubing, bottles, IV sets, syringes without needles.

Yellow bag (Option B): For human/animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, expired medicines, and chemical waste requiring incineration or deep burial.

Green bag (Option D): Not part of BMW 2016 colour coding for biomedical waste disposal in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the hospital with cellulitis. After 3 days, he develops abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and cough with fever, with pneumonia also suspected. What is the most likely mode of spread of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely mode of spread is inhalation of aerosols from contaminated artificial aquatic sources, such as air conditioners, cooling towers, and shower heads. Legionella pneumophila is a Gram-negative, thin, non-capsulated bacillus that causes Legionnaires' disease (severe pneumonia) and Pontiac fever (milder flu-like illness). Infections typically present with fever, non-productive cough, dyspnoea, chest pain, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain.

  • Reservoir: No natural human reservoir; the organism survives in aquatic environments.
  • Transmission: Airborne spread via inhalation of contaminated aerosols; no human-to-human transmission.
  • Epidemiology: Associated with contaminated water systems and devices producing aerosols.
  • Pathogenesis: Multiplies in monocytes and macrophages, evading killing.
  • Incubation: Legionnaires' disease - 2-10 days; Pontiac fever - 1-2 days.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sexual contact (Option A): Mode of spread for organisms like HIV, Hepatitis B, Syphilis, Gonorrhea, Chlamydia, and HPV, not for Legionella.

Contaminated milk products (Option B): Transmits Brucella and Listeria monocytogenes, not Legionella.

Contaminated meat (Option C): Transmits Toxoplasma gondii and Trichinella spiralis, not Legionella.

questions.text: A patient with aspiration pneumonia is being treated with clindamycin. After 3 days of treatment, the patient develops profuse watery diarrhoea. What is the most likely cause of this new symptom?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely cause of profuse watery diarrhoea after 3 days of clindamycin therapy is Pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridioides difficile infection. Prolonged hospital stay is a major risk factor for acquiring this infection in healthcare settings.

  • Causative organism: Clostridioides difficile - Gram-positive, spore-forming, obligate anaerobic bacillus.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Produces high-molecular-weight exotoxins A (enterotoxin) and B (cytotoxin).
    • Toxin A → fluid secretion and mucosal inflammation.
    • Toxin B → cytopathic effects and colonic epithelial damage.
  • Common risk factors:
    • Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., clindamycin, ampicillin, cephalosporins).
    • Prolonged hospital stay.
    • The elderly age group.
    • Gastrointestinal surgery.
    • Antacid use (reducing gastric acidity).
  • Clinical features: Watery diarrhoea (may be bloody in severe cases), abdominal pain, fever; may lead to toxic megacolon.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Endoscopic visualisation of pseudomembranes.
    • Detection of toxins A and/or B in stool via ELISA.
    • Culture on selective media.
  • Treatment:
    • Stop the inciting antibiotic.
    • Initiate vancomycin or metronidazole.
    • In recurrent cases, faecal microbiota transplantation may be considered.

Explanation of Other Options:

Trauma during interventional procedure (Option A): May cause local injury or bleeding, but is not typically associated with profuse watery diarrhoea.

Increased use of IV cannula (Option B): Raises risk of bloodstream infections, not gastrointestinal infections like C. difficile.

Prolonged catheterisation (Option D): Increases risk of urinary tract infections, not antibiotic-associated diarrhoea.

choices.text: Treatment to be based on culture reports

questions.text: Antibiotic stewardship involves all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The core aim of antibiotic stewardship is to optimise the use of antibiotics to improve patient outcomes, reduce microbial resistance, and decrease unnecessary costs. It includes measures to ensure appropriate selection, dosing, route, and duration of antibiotic therapy. Control of infection, although crucial for patient safety, is part of a broader infection control program and not a direct element of antibiotic stewardship.

  • Prescribing antibiotics only when indicated - avoid unnecessary use, especially in viral illnesses.
  • Restricting inappropriate antibiotic use - including limiting 3rd/4th generation agents unless justified.
  • Using susceptibility data - rational antibiotic choice based on microbiology results.
  • Adequate dosage and correct duration - prevents under-dosing and resistance development.
  • Implementation in critical care units, where antibiotic resistance risk is highest.

Explanation of Other Options:

Prescribing antibiotics only when needed (Option A): A fundamental principle to prevent overuse and resistance.

Prescribing antibiotics with adequate dosage (Option C): Ensures therapeutic effectiveness while minimising the risk of resistance.

Treatment to be based on culture reports (Option D): Stewardship emphasises basing treatment on culture and sensitivity results to ensure targeted therapy.

questions.text: A patient undergoing treatment for sepsis requires intubation and, after 4 days, develops fever. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is suspected. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The initial step after suspecting VAP is to confirm the presence of new pulmonary infiltrates on imaging. A chest X-ray is the preferred first-line investigation to assess for radiological evidence of pneumonia before proceeding to further diagnostic work-up.

  • Clinical Presentation of VAP:
    • New or progressive pulmonary infiltrates on imaging
    • Increased respiratory secretions
    • Worsening oxygenation, reduced tidal volumes, increased inspiratory pressures
    • Systemic signs: fever, leukocytosis, tachycardia
  • Diagnostic Approach:
    • Imaging:
      • Chest X-ray to detect new or worsening infiltrates (first step).
      • A CT scan may be considered if the diagnosis remains unclear.
    • Microbiological Evaluation:
      • Sputum sample (spontaneous or induced)
      • Endotracheal aspirate or bronchoalveolar lavage for culture and sensitivity
    • Other supportive investigations: Blood cultures, inflammatory markers.
  • Common Pathogens in VAP:
    • Klebsiella pneumoniae
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
    • Staphylococcus aureus
    • Enterobacter species
    • Acinetobacter baumannii
  • Prevention Measures in Ventilated Patients:
    • Maintain head of bed elevation (30-45°)
    • Daily sedation vacation and assessment for extubation
    • Oral care with chlorhexidine
    • Proper maintenance of endotracheal tube cuff pressure

Clinical Presentation: New pulmonary infiltrates. Increased respiratory secretions. Signs of worsened respiratory status, such as worsening oxygenation, lower tidal volumes, and increased inspiratory pressure. Systemic signs of infection, such as fever, leukocytosis, and tachycardia.

Explanation of Other Options:

CT scan (Option B): More sensitive than X-ray but not used as the first-line imaging due to higher cost, radiation exposure, and limited immediate availability in ICU settings.

Sputum culture (Option C): Important for confirming the pathogen and guiding antibiotic therapy, but is done after radiological confirmation of pneumonia.

All of the above (Option D): Not correct, as the initial step is imaging (Chest X-ray) before proceeding to other diagnostic modalities.
